description: Borrowed from Middle French rupture, or its source, Latin ruptūra (“a breaking, rupture (of a limb or vein)”) and Medieval Latin ruptūra (“a road, a field, a form of feudal tenure, a tax, etc.”), from the participle stem of rumpere (“to break, burst”).

entries.meaning: A social breach or break, between individuals or groups.
examples: He knew that policy would disincline Napoleon from a rupture with his family.

entries.meaning: (medicine) A break or tear in soft tissue, such as a muscle.
(engineering) A failure mode in which a tough ductile material pulls apart rather than cracking.

verbs.description: rupture (third-person singular simple present ruptures, present participle rupturing, simple past and past participle ruptured)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To burst, break through, or split, as under pressure.
